projectDesc.p: To the tune “Joys of Day and Night”—"The bedroom remembers the day we first met" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.
Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

app.rdg: To the tune “Joys of Day and Night”
The bedroom remembers the day we first met,
It seemed that we would be together forever.
How could I have known that an encounter of secret joy
Would end in the pain and sorrow of parting?
Not to mention that it happened when the declining spring beauty came to its end.
Facing a full sight of disarrayed flowers and whirling catkins,
Would all go away with him.
A plight of loneliness— whom should I talk to?
People say that words in the past are always easy to discard.
Had I only realized how hard it is to leave the words behind!
I regret that I did not make him stay.
What can I do besides be charming and good mannered?
He, too, has something that ties one’s heart.
Even when I am not thinking about him the entire day,
My eyebrows frown a thousand times.
